snippet.textDisplay: While I'm a big fan of LTT, and watch almost daily, This video annoyed me quite a bit. I'm a 47 year old hard working Joe in the U.K., and I struggle to keep my PC useful as a gaming machine. This is a money consideration, not a technical consideration, as I've been building PC's for years. So what annoyed me about this video was a few phone calls got you three petabytes of storage for free, and I am constantly jockeying my games across two terabytes of storage on my machine. How about some more video's for us budget gamers Linus?? While i like the ultimate machines you play with, these are just pipe dreams for most of your viewers.

How about some more video's for us budget gamers Linus?? While i like the ultimate machines you play with, these are just pipe dreams for most of your viewers.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you want write cache security, then look into datacenter solutions.
The front line of your defense is A/B power links. You have the redundant power supplies are on different circuits so that a fault on one circuit will not necessarily cause a problem.
The second line of your defense is a UPS for each power supply. If the power goes down that can (and should) be set to immediately notify all connected servers and services, and fire off an alert to the on-call tech notifying them of the problem (Optionally via a dedicated cell connection - it's actually surprisingly cheap to have a data-only SIM if you use it exclusively for notifications. Seriously, like $5/mo), and then ensures the system stays up long enough to finish all cached writes and shuts down cleanly.
The third line of your defense is an automatic failover bypass so that a UPS failure results in the system switching away from the UPS and sending a notification. A lot of UPS systems can do this internally.
The fourth line of your defense is the use of a battery backed write cache, which requires SAS controllers that have that sort of capability. In the event of a disaster, such as the power cables somehow becoming dislodged, Linus, then these will preserve any writes in-flight until they can be written to disk.

Unrelated: If you've got a lot of old drives and systems you don't want anymore, why not wipe them and give them away? Make it an essay writing contest or something.
snippet.textOriginal:
If you want write cache security, then look into datacenter solutions.
The front line of your defense is A/B power links. You have the redundant power supplies are on different circuits so that a fault on one circuit will not necessarily cause a problem.
The second line of your defense is a UPS for each power supply. If the power goes down that can (and should) be set to immediately notify all connected servers and services, and fire off an alert to the on-call tech notifying them of the problem (Optionally via a dedicated cell connection - it's actually surprisingly cheap to have a data-only SIM if you use it exclusively for notifications. Seriously, like $5/mo), and then ensures the system stays up long enough to finish all cached writes and shuts down cleanly.
The third line of your defense is an automatic failover bypass so that a UPS failure results in the system switching away from the UPS and sending a notification. A lot of UPS systems can do this internally.
The fourth line of your defense is the use of a battery backed write cache, which requires SAS controllers that have that sort of capability. In the event of a disaster, such as the power cables somehow becoming dislodged, Linus, then these will preserve any writes in-flight until they can be written to disk.

Unrelated: If you've got a lot of old drives and systems you don't want anymore, why not wipe them and give them away? Make it an essay writing contest or something.

snippet.textDisplay:
I love these huge builds for the just-because-we-can chutzpah.


But even when you might someday need to look at 5 year old data the reality is that most old data just sits there. Long before data stores get this big I'd be looking at a near-online tape library. We've been doing that for 40 years now, so it's mature technology. It might never make for good Youtube content but it's a sight more efficient than ever increasing piles of spinning rust.


And what about tiered storage? Cache for current access, SSD frequent access, disc occasional access, tape for history.
snippet.textOriginal:
I love these huge builds for the just-because-we-can chutzpah.


But even when you might someday need to look at 5 year old data the reality is that most old data just sits there. Long before data stores get this big I'd be looking at a near-online tape library. We've been doing that for 40 years now, so it's mature technology. It might never make for good Youtube content but it's a sight more efficient than ever increasing piles of spinning rust.  


And what about tiered storage?  Cache for current access, SSD frequent access, disc occasional access, tape for history.

snippet.textDisplay: It's not 3 petabytes, but our new array has 500TB of SSD storage in a RAID 50 array. I did setup a RAID 100 array with it, just for kicks to see how it worked out (and it did once I got the right controllers), but frankly the hardware "tax" for that level of redundancy was unjustifiable for our implementation.
snippet.textOriginal: It's not 3 petabytes, but our new array has 500TB of SSD storage in a RAID 50 array. I did setup a RAID 100 array with it, just for kicks to see how it worked out (and it did once I got the right controllers), but frankly the hardware "tax" for that level of redundancy was unjustifiable for our implementation.

snippet.textDisplay:
20 years ago I predicted petabyte storage systems. To all those naysers back then: I TOLD YOU SO.
In 1987 I bought a "huge" drive: 33 MB. It cost me around $500 (over $1000 in 2020 dollars.). I estimate the petabyte stourage could be built for about $30,000. Adjusting for inflation that would have bought around 450 MB in 1987. Storage has increased by two million times in 33 years.
snippet.textOriginal:
20 years ago I predicted petabyte storage systems. To all those naysers back then: I TOLD YOU SO.
In 1987 I bought a "huge" drive: 33 MB. It cost me around $500  (over $1000 in 2020 dollars.). I estimate the petabyte stourage could be built for about $30,000. Adjusting for inflation that would have bought around 450 MB in 1987. Storage has increased by two million times in 33 years.

snippet.textDisplay:
Most of LTT vids are just reviews/ building stuff, except a few where they test things and show technical stuff.
I've seen many YT channels, that use just iphone/GoPro and a simple Nikon Z50 for all the videos and they are just fine.
So, what is the need for all this over the board excessive use of 8K video shoot by RED camera gear that's used for
making movies and hoard 1000's of TB worth of data? All this for a bunch of review videos?? Is LTT gone insane?
Among 10M subs, what is the % of people, who watch LTT vids on 4k moniters?
So, just to satisfy the 0.01% they're working this hard. It's cute, though.
I've seen many times they talk about productivity and price during the GPU reviews, but don't seem to own up them.
At this rate, they're gonna run out of this 3PB in a year and like ppl. in comments, they may even buy Segate/ WD, LMAO

snippet.textDisplay: It's cool that seagate sent you a bunch of free drives, but you shouldn't recommend them for storage. They have terrible reliability. Even their pro line, proven time and again, their drives have a very high failure rate. It's the brand I would recommend the least.
snippet.textOriginal: It's cool that seagate sent you a bunch of free drives, but you shouldn't recommend them for storage. They have terrible reliability. Even their pro line, proven time and again, their drives have a very high failure rate. It's the brand I would recommend the least.

snippet.textDisplay: Picked up a 6TB IronWolf drive for my games to go on when I needed more space and my 1 TB, 1.5 TB and 2 TB were all full of games. My computer is almost always on so I was looking at 6 TB, 7200 rpm drives and saw the Ironwolf drives were the best price. Hoping to get some more of them so that I can setup my server and NAS systems plus get some more storage into my gaming system.
snippet.textOriginal: Picked up a 6TB IronWolf drive for my games to go on when I needed more space and my 1 TB, 1.5 TB and 2 TB were all full of games. My computer is almost always on so I was looking at 6 TB, 7200 rpm drives and saw the Ironwolf drives were the best price. Hoping to get some more of them so that I can setup my server and NAS systems plus get some more storage into my gaming system.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've modded my gaming laptop to hold 12tb total raw storage, but after a year it is filled to the brim. Then decided to upgraded it to 14tb total raw storage, but now under 6mo.s it is almost full again. 😭
It would be awesome to have 2 Micron 7.68tb ssds, 1 sabrent 4tb m.2 nvme ssd and 4tb m.2 ssd installed in my laptop to max it out at total of 21.36TB raw storage installed on a gaming laptop. 😅
I bought a external drive from seagate, a 10tb skyhawk surveillance drive to save all of my games.
snippet.textOriginal:
I've modded my gaming laptop to hold 12tb total raw storage, but after a year it is filled to the brim. Then decided to upgraded it to 14tb total raw storage, but now under 6mo.s it is almost full again. 😭
It would be awesome to have 2 Micron 7.68tb ssds, 1 sabrent 4tb m.2 nvme ssd and 4tb m.2 ssd installed in my laptop to max it out at total of 21.36TB raw storage installed on a gaming laptop. 😅
I bought a external drive from seagate, a 10tb skyhawk surveillance drive to save all of my games.
